text:
<@U01P13NTGG6> Still, it seems like just about everyone hits a point where they dislike this cycle. Makes me think there must be something inherently messed up about it that needs fixing.

Also, it doesn't work. The ROI on it is extremely low most of the time, and it seems like it annoys people more often than it draws them in. The tactics are often unethical or at least slightly deceptive, yet people accept it as part of the sales game.

I'm looking to get off that hamster wheel into something better.

text:
Hi friends!

I'm in a weird spot and would love your advice. For the first time in my eight-year content career, I'm not getting many responses to applications I send out. Currently I'm Content Lead at a small startup, looking to join a larger company as a Senior/Managing Editor, Senior Content Marketing Manager, or Senior Content Writer, depending on the field/company. I send a cover letter with every application and the hiring managers I've heard from say it's impactful, so I'm not sure where I'm going wrong.

I started sending my CV out in earnest two weeks ago. Is it possible that recruiters are just completely underwater and I should expect to wait longer? I recently moved from Israel to the US, so maybe my skills were in higher demand there? Am I doing something wrong?

CV attached for feedback, LinkedIn <http://www.linkedin.com/in/slhodkin|here>. 

Thank you!

elements.text: Hi friends!

I'm in a weird spot and would love your advice. For the first time in my eight-year content career, I'm not getting many responses to applications I send out. I send a cover letter with every application and the hiring managers I've heard from say it's impactful, so I'm not sure where I'm going wrong.

I started sending my CV out in earnest two weeks ago. Is it possible that recruiters are just completely underwater and I should expect to wait longer? I recently moved from Israel to the US, so maybe my skills were in higher demand there? Am I doing something wrong?
CV attached for feedback, LinkedIn
here
Thank you!

text:
I feel you! I also despise "sales". But I have a successful freelance writing/editing business.

I get most of my clients through referrals at this point. A handful through LinkedIn. And, once in a while, a client or two through cold emails.

However, my cold emails are never generic, and I never send them to random companies. I always make sure that I have some kind of connection to them, which makes it more "lukewarm" than cold (haha).

What's worked for me is really putting the work into figuring out my target client and focusing on them. I have a long list of what I'm looking for in a client and contract, so I only spend time pursuing those who fit the bill. This makes my efforts more targeted, and, typically, provides a higher ROI.

Of course, it depends on where you are in your career and the experience you have.

text:
Hi Shayna! It looks like you have great experience. Most recruiters likely are not getting through your resume and truly appreciating that due to its length. Recruiters are reviewing hundreds of resumes so giving them something they can quickly read and say “yep, she's got it!” helps.

For US-based companies I would recommend a one page resume as the standard (two if you absolutely must). It's more digestible and, when I read it later as the HM, also shows me that you can edit down to the highest impact accomplishments. I don't think you need both the summary and bullet points for each role and you can likely decrease the line spacing, but will need to condense overall. The cover letter is a great place to provide that summary context and connect it to the role you're applying for.

elements.text: Hi Shayna! It looks like you have great experience. Most recruiters likely are not getting through your resume and truly appreciating that due to its length. I don't think you need both the summary and bullet points for each role and you can likely decrease the line spacing, but will need to condense overall. The cover letter is a great place to provide that summary context and connect it to the role you're applying for.

text: And two weeks isn't very long so I wouldn't be worried yet—especially if you're being selective with where you apply. Sometimes getting interviews is a numbers game as there are so many factors happening behind-the-scenes in the hiring process/timeline.

text:
Hey <@UKAK6J1NY>, i work in recruitment marketing and while your can cut down your resume, honestly your length doesn't matter all that much. Yes a quick read is helpful however, a recruiter is going to be be looking for very specific details that align to what is listed exactly in the JD.

Are you tailoring your resume for each position?

My suggestions are

• taking out the line “my day to day responsibilities” (it's clear the bullet points are your responsibilities)
• however — update bullet points to focus on achievements instead responsibilities using the X,y.z formula: I did x, through y, and the impact was z. Use it to tell a very short and consists story 
• Try and use the exact wording from the JD in your resume/bullet points. (in case they run your resume through an ATS system where the scan for key words)
• list out key competencies (hard and soft skills) in a section of its own. Bullet points should be your achievements and it will be easier to see your skills separately

text:
And when I think of editing roles, I would lean into showcasing how your drove, Influenced, or directed strategy.

It's clear your content writer but I don't see anything that clearly screams HOW you lead, influenced,
Or developed as editor/manager— a lot of what your wrote outlines what you executed on a day to day as a writer so the story you're trying to paint can be unclear to recruiter as to what you're really looking for

text: I agree with the other comments so far - the opening line in intro saying you’re a writer and editor doesn’t necessarily speak to the strategic and leadership skills you may want to highlight for more senior roles. A hiring manager may stop there and think to themselves, “I need a strategic leader with writing and editing skills, not just a writer/editor” and move on.

text:
I'd disagree there. 

You can customize per role with very simple edits, w especially if you have one master resume where you “dump” all your skills, experiences, in one document. Then you make a copy of that, and cut refuse and infuse what you do and Don't need based on the JD.

It should never be a major overall every time; just edited so it's meeting exactly what is asked 

Ideally, you should be thinking about the ideal opportunity or opportunities you looking for as you stated <@URAV154AV> and have resumes that reflect that.

Def not feasible if you're applying to different industries, with very different responsibilities

text: Shayna it may also be worth skipping applying and messaging the recruiting/talent/hiring managers directly to express your interest. It can be very hard for recruiters/hirers to wade through applications online (they get inundated with not-so-great-applications). One look at your LI years of exp. should help them contact you faster if you’re a fit! (IMHO)

text:
Nobody outside of marketing appreciates how much time, energy & resources are needed to create impactful content!

Some ideas to gain agreement on:
1. Content pillars
What are the top 2-3 problems your company solves? What makes you unique? Gain agreement and organize your content under these themes.
For example: “Making complex things simple”
or “Leaving a legacy”

2.  Content strategy and roadmap
What are the bare minimum pieces of content that each product should have?
How does this align to how your customers make decisions?
Create a checklist, so that when a product name changes, they can see that this means 42 updates across your content.

3. Content creation process
Theoretically, you should all agree on the content pillars, then create a list of topics that fall under each pillar. The topics can change (depending on market situation, customer priorities, buying stage, etc), but your pillars should not.  Gain agreement on when you should be brought into the process. And educate people on why consistency is important. (Most companies get bored with their strategy/ message long before the market even knows who they are).

4. Lastly, as <@U02BTBBH887> pointed out — this is a much bigger issue than a content one. Sounds like nobody is leading the charge on what customers want, how your company provides unique value and THEN how the company goes to market.

This is a recurring problem in most scaling b2b companies that are led by non-marketers.

or “Leaving a legacy”

2.  Content strategy and roadmap

How does this align to how your customers make decisions?
Create a checklist, so that when a product name changes, they can see that this means 42 updates across your content.

3. Content creation process
Theoretically, you should all agree on the content pillars, then create a list of topics that fall under each pillar. And educate people on why consistency is important. (Most companies get bored with their strategy/ message long before the market even knows who they are).

4. Lastly, as

pointed out — this is a much bigger issue than a content one. Sounds like nobody is leading the charge on what customers want, how your company provides unique value and THEN how the company goes to market.

This is a recurring problem in most scaling b2b companies that are led by non-marketers.

text:
Echoing <@U036K0S6AQJ> on hiring on an editor. I built our blog program out (SEO manager here) and I started by directly managing a handful of freelance writers + content agency + CMS uploaders, but my first hire was a managing editor to handle day-to-day production for all SEO content (blog, product descriptions), editing, and freelancer management because i was IN THE WEEDS. Best decision I made to have someone dedicated to managing the content production process, but it sounds like that might be closer to your role? It did allow me to take a step back and think more strategically about the content we were creating and optimizing.

Now that I no longer have headcount for in-house, I've transitioned back to content agency (who we've worked with for almost 2 years and really understands our voice and turns in clean copy), one freelance editor, and 2 freelance CMS uploaders. I'll assign out to a freelance writer with subject matter expertise. Allows me to keep the content production machine running pretty much self sufficiently after I've planned out the editorial cal, and then I batch review published content and also batch create assigning briefs so i have time for the rest of my SEOland stuff.

If my job was just managing content, I'd bring on an editor with some CMS experience and freelance the rest out, depending on budgets. Also would be helpful to have someone with experience in off-page that can execute any strategies there (content distribution etc). My agency also helps with graphic design requests my internal creative team is too swamped to support. Happy to pass along their info to anyone looking for a great agency — I've worked with a few and generally hate agencies (no offense everyone! Im really picky about my content), and the one I work with now is really top notch.

text: I switched to a job I knew wasnt going to be a good fit for me purely for the salary and I was miserable. Def second going somewhere you can grow and where you'll feel valued and are aligned with company culture

text:
<@UKAK6J1NY> I'm in the middle of hiring for an editor role right now, so this sort of thing is top of mind.

Lots of good advice here, especially the point about focusing on results rather than responsibilities. So many resumes I've looked at only talk about what someone did, not how well they did it.

And going back to a mention further up in the thread, a cover letter will help set you apart too. Especially if it's optional. It shows an additional level of investment and complements the resume in a way that gives a snapshot of your personality. Based on the cover letters I've reviewed, one suggestion to really help yours stand out is tell a story with it. Telling me you're good at this or you have that skill doesn't actually tell me anything. Share an example, weave a short story. Help the recruiter/hiring manager see the value you can bring in tangible ways.

Just some thoughts based on what I've seen going through this from the manager's side. Hope that helps! Feel free to DM me if you have any questions.

text: Hey Superpath community! Are there any Content Marketing Managers who made the switch to Product Marketing Managers? Would love to learn why and how you made the transition. Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey Superpath community! Are there any Content Marketing Managers who made the switch to Product Marketing Managers? Would love to learn why and how you made the transition. Thanks

text:
I am a firm believer in a human-centered digital marketing approach. It is literally the focus of my business.

I think there is a lot of room to go about these traditional routes with a different perspective and focus that can respect the people on the other side of the screen as humans while still accomplishing sales and marketing goals.

Honestly, my best advice is to only ever send/push/publish what would make you feel comfortable being on the receiving end of, if that makes sense.

Meaning don't send a cold email that you wouldn't want to receive and read. Does this mean your cold emails now need to have personal research, specific examples, etc. and will take a lot more work? Yes. But it just feels far less icky (and, in my opinion, will be far more effective).

text:
Hi <@U02333AMCUW>, I've made the switch between content management and product marketing several times. I think my sweet spot is somewhere in the middle, so it depends a lot on how a company defines each role.

I'm drawn to product marketing because I love the higher-level strategic thinking: understanding the market, the competition, a company's value propositions, and how to do positioning well. I don't love the sitting-in-lots-of-meetings part, but I suppose that's how you "get alignment."

I'm drawn to content marketing because I love building and executing things: writing, editing, promoting, and listening. I don't love the lower salaries for this role or what feels like a marketing movement from value-driven storytelling into SEO gamification, but I suppose that's the way the :cookie: crumbles.

Are you considering a transition? What do you see as the pros + cons?

I'm drawn to content marketing because I love building and executing things: writing, editing, promoting, and listening. I don't love the lower salaries for this role or what feels like a marketing movement from value-driven storytelling into SEO gamification, but I suppose that's the way the

crumbles.

Are you considering a transition? What do you see as the pros + cons?

text:
I tend to think slow and steady is more effective anyway :shrug::skin-tone-4: your opens and responses are likely going to be way higher.

However, there is another take that I've stumbled across that is basically going with templates that have hyper-specific personalization added before sending.

Maybe that's a happy medium?

text:
Thank you so much, <@U024BHRFEPQ>! That makes a lot of sense.

I’d be curious to hear more about your agency. I’m not actively looking for one at the moment, but I’ve always been agency-skeptical myself and would love to keep them in mind for the future!

text: ive inherited agencies twice and always disliked them. It felt like they were just writing Google research papers and didnt really understand the brand. Going with a super boutique one has been a complete change, and they're like part of the SEO family here. Feel free to message me and I can make the connect
